subtitle: Helping customers understand their energy journey

detailMetrics.label: Translated backend states like into human language
Customer has autonomy to understand their journey
From unreliable email system to just one click

contentBlocks.quote: Can somebody explain to me how this switching thing go?
contentBlocks.context: As a freelance & foreigner with zero knowledge of the British energy market, I had to piece together a system that even the engineers couldn't fully explain; then make it friendly enough for anxious customers waiting weeks for their switch.

blocks.text: Switching energy suppliers in the UK is a weeks-long process—that's just how it works. Behind the scenes, there's a complex choreography: your old supplier needs to approve the transfer, industry databases need updating, meter readings get verified, and about a dozen other things have to happen in the right order.

Most energy companies handle this by sending customers occasional email updates as they hit major milestones. The problem? If something gets stuck—a debt objection, a meter access issue, a database mismatch—the silence between emails can stretch on for days or weeks.

Anxious customers start calling support to check on their switch, clogging up customer service lines. The frustrating part? Half the time, the bottleneck isn't even the energy company's fault—it's the previous supplier dragging their feet, a bank payment issue, a meter reading problem, or something else entirely in the switching ecosystem.

blocks.html: Tomato's specific challenge? Their email system was notoriously unreliable:

items: Notifications often failed to send altogether
Emails arrived delayed, sometimes days after the actual status change
Outdated data meant customers were seeing old information
No way to proactively check status—just wait and hope for an email

blocks.text: This created a double problem: customers had no visibility into an already opaque process, and support couldn't reliably direct them to "check your email" when those emails weren't arriving.

blocks.html: Oh, and one more thing: no one at Tomato could actually explain how the full switching process worked—not customer service, not even the backend engineers who'd each built their slice of it. No documentation existed. Just a technical flow diagram that meant nothing to anyone outside the dev team.

contentBlocks.heading: From Email Chaos to Self-Service Clarity

before.label: The Old Way
items: Multiple (often failed) email notifications
"Did you get our email?" support tickets
No visibility into delays or bottlenecks
Generic 'processing' messages with no context
Customers completely in the dark about who was responsible for delays

after.label: The New Experience
items: One magic link email to personalised microsite
Direct real-time backend connection
Clear bottleneck diagnosis showing whose fault and why
Contextual actions for each state
Self-service transparency that eliminated support queries

blocks.text: One Email, One Link

Bypassed Tomato's unreliable email system entirely. Instead of multiple (often failed) notifications throughout the journey, customers received one magic link to access their personalised tracking microsite—directly connected to the backend, always up to date.
Clear Status Communication
Translated 15+ technical backend states into four human-readable stages:

items: Application — "We've received your switch request"
Switch Initiation — "Your current supplier has been notified"
Approval — "Good news! Your switch is approved for [date]"
Completion — "Welcome! You're now on Tomato"

blocks.text: Transparent Bottleneck Diagnosis

Designed the interface to clearly show where delays were happening and whose fault they were. "Your switch is delayed because your previous supplier hasn't approved the transfer" beats silence or generic "processing" messages every time.
Two Journey Types
Built parallel experiences for different meter types:

items: Smart meters: Automated reading collection, fewer manual steps
Traditional meters: Clear callouts when manual readings were required

blocks.text: Error Categorisation
Created clear error messaging across three categories:

items: Application errors: Wrong MPAN, incorrect address, missing information
Switching errors: Debt objections, contract disputes, supplier blocking
Technical issues: Meter access problems, database mismatches, system failures

blocks.text: Each error included actionable next steps instead of vague "something went wrong" messages.
Brand Personality
Added loading animations—tomatoes falling from the top, a small bouncing tomato at the bottom—to keep Tomato's playful personality alive during data fetches and make waiting feel less anxious.

contentBlocks.title: Design as Documentation
contentBlocks.insight: The final prototype became the single source of truth for how Tomato's switching process actually worked—something no one at the company could explain before I started.
contentBlocks.result: Referenced by other teams after delivery. Sometimes the best way to get clarity is to start designing and let the process force the right questions.

blocks.text: Created a customer touchpoint that didn't exist before, turning an opaque industry process into something transparent and manageable.
Worked around unreliable email infrastructure by designing a single-link solution that gave customers direct backend access—no more "did you get our email?" support tickets.
Let customers see exactly where bottlenecks were and whose responsibility they were, eliminating unnecessary "where's my switch?" queries and reducing support burden.
Pieced together a complex system flow that no single person at the company could explain—starting from ground zero as a non-UK resident learning the British energy market.
Took scattered brand materials and evolved them into a cohesive, delightful tracking experience that felt unmistakably "Tomato."
Designed for mobile-only launch to get value in customers' hands quickly, proving that strategic constraints can accelerate delivery.

Key Takeaways: Engineers know more than they think
